questions.question: What is non-shivering thermogenesis primarily mediated by?

questions.correctAnswer: B. Hormones increasing metabolic rate (e.g., adrenalin, thyroxin)

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: What is shivering thermogenesis?
options: A. Heat production via hormonal increase in metabolism
C. Heat production via involuntary muscle contractions
questions.correctAnswer: C. Heat production via involuntary muscle contractions

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism for decreasing heat loss in response to cold?
options: B. Vasodilation of skin blood vessels
C. Vasoconstriction of skin blood vessels
questions.correctAnswer: C. Vasoconstriction of skin blood vessels

questions.correctAnswer: D. Skin, Internal organs, and Spinal Cord

questions.question: According to Young's Model of Cold Acclimatisation, 'cold habituation' involves which physiological changes?
options: A. Enhanced shivering and enhanced non-shivering thermogenesis
B. Blunted shivering and blunted cutaneous vasoconstriction
C. Enhanced cutaneous vasoconstriction and improved muscle blood flow
questions.correctAnswer: B. Blunted shivering and blunted cutaneous vasoconstriction

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: What is the 'Hunter reflex' or cold-induced vasodilation (CIVD)?
options: A. Continuous severe vasoconstriction in the cold
B. Cyclical vasoconstriction and vasodilation in peripheral tissues during cold exposure
C. A sudden drop in core body temperature upon entering cold water
questions.correctAnswer: B. Cyclical vasoconstriction and vasodilation in peripheral tissues during cold exposure

questions.question: Why might rapid rewarming be dangerous in subchronic (urban) hypothermia?
options: B. It can reverse fluid shifts too quickly, potentially causing pulmonary oedema.
D. It prevents the kidneys from functioning.
questions.correctAnswer: B. It can reverse fluid shifts too quickly, potentially causing pulmonary oedema.

questions.question: Heat exhaustion is often due to depletion of what?

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: What is a key difference between heat exhaustion and heatstroke regarding core temperature and CNS function?
options: A. Heat exhaustion has higher core temp (>40°C) and CNS dysfunction; heatstroke does not.
B. Heatstroke has higher core temp (>40°C) and CNS dysfunction; heat exhaustion usually does not.
C. Both have similar core temperatures, but only heatstroke involves sweating.
D. Both involve CNS dysfunction, but only heat exhaustion has high core temperatures.
questions.correctAnswer: B. Heatstroke has higher core temp (>40°C) and CNS dysfunction; heat exhaustion usually does not.

questions.question: In hyperthermia, what damaging process occurs to proteins, impairing cellular function?

questions.question: What is the most effective behavioural response to feeling cold?
options: C. Adding layers of clothing or seeking shelter
questions.correctAnswer: C. Adding layers of clothing or seeking shelter

questions.question: Vasodilation of subcutaneous vessels primarily aids in which process?

questions.question: Why might thermogenesis be reduced in the elderly?
options: B. Reduced skeletal muscle mass and endocrine changes
questions.correctAnswer: B. Reduced skeletal muscle mass and endocrine changes

questions.question: Why are newborns particularly susceptible to heat loss?
options: B. Large surface area-to-body mass ratio and less subcutaneous fat
questions.correctAnswer: B. Large surface area-to-body mass ratio and less subcutaneous fat

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: What is the primary mechanism newborns use for heat production, since they cannot shiver effectively?
options: C. Non-shivering thermogenesis in brown fat
questions.correctAnswer: C. Non-shivering thermogenesis in brown fat

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: Why is the average core body temperature difference between young and elderly adults clinically relevant when assessing for fever?
options: A. It's irrelevant as fever definitions are absolute.
B. Elderly adults have a higher baseline, making fever harder to detect.
C. Elderly adults have a lower baseline, so a lower temperature may indicate fever.
D. Fever doesn't occur in elderly adults.
questions.correctAnswer: C. Elderly adults have a lower baseline, so a lower temperature may indicate fever.
